Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Generic Portfolio Review Tool

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this grant is to develop a portfolio review tool (PRT). The PRT will be a computerized tool with a set of coding sheets that guide reviewers through a targeted set of decision rules and questions to record information relevant to a program's portfolio. The primary goal of this exploratory project is to develop a generic, versatile, and multipurpose tool that helps evaluators conduct a systematic and comprehensive review of projects designed to advance STEM education.

As part of the PRT development effort, the PIs will first develop a unifying logic model for STEM education and a set of common metrics that are designed to guide and inform the overall process of portfolio review. Additionally, a set of common metrics will be developed to assess progress toward desired outcomes (e.g., whether long-term goals have been accomplished, whether investments yielded products and impacts). Next, they will develop a prototype PRT with the Microsoft ACCESS database system. It will be pilot tested for usability on a sample of up to six programs across directorates that vary in several portfolio dimensions (e.g., evaluation, broad impact). After revising the prototype tool on the basis of the results of the pilot test (e.g., user interface, inter-rater reliability), the PIs will convert it to a Web-based tool with basic functionality (e.g., data entry, search) and design features. Lastly, a field test will be conducted on a different sample of up to three programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to develop a tool for reviewing and analyzing NSF's investment portfolio in STEM education research and development. The ultimate goal of the project was to help NSF build its capacity to conduct systematic portfolio reviews and gather information about the quality, relevance, and impact of investments in STEM education efforts across programs within Directorate for Education and Human Resources (EHR). To that end, we completed a number of activities: Literature review, development of logic model and portfolio coding guide, development of portfolio review tool (PRT), and pilot-test of the PRT.

Literature Review: We conducted a comprehensive review of literature relevant to investments in STEM education R&D, extant portfolio reviews, and program evaluations. For example, we examined key NSF documents and a sample of NSF program solicitations. As a result, we designed our PRT to map individual project's goals, plans, designs, and outcomes to NSF's strategic and performance goals and targets as outlined in the NSF Strategic Plans for FY 2011-2016.

Development of Logic Model and Portfolio Coding Guide and Other Supportive Activities: We built a logic model which helped us capture key components of portfolio review (e.g., goals, inputs, designs and strategies of project activities, outputs, and outcomes) and structure the relationships among the portfolio components.  In additional, we created a portfolio coding guide which specified a set of variables to classify, code, and analyze EHR projects.

In light of the CoSTEM’s Federal STEM Education 5Year Strategic Plan released in May 2013, we aligned our portfolio coding guide with the Strategic Plan. Specifically, we revised our draft coding guide by taking into account the federal government’s new strategic vision, and national goals. For example, the STEM Strategic Plan set ambitious national goals to drive federal investment in five priority STEM education investment areas: (1) Improvement STEM instruction, (2) increase and sustain youth and public engagement in STEM, (3) enhance STEM experience of undergraduate students, (4) better serve groups historically underrepresented in STEM Fields, and (5) design graduate education for tomorrow’s STEM workforce.

In addition, we used the conceptual framework of the CoSTEM’s Federal STEM Education Portfolio report (2011) to take an inventory of STEM education programs in terms of main objectives, target beneficiary, services and products, and R&D continuum. For example, the CoSTEM’s Portfolio report provided a classification of objectives of education investment such as learning, engagement, educator performance, and education R&D.

As part of activities to support our PRT development effort, we conducted a secondary data analysis of the raw federal STEM education inventory data. Further, we explored topic modeling as a new approach to better characterize STEM education portfolio. Topic modeling is designed to help identify and understand underlying themes that are buried in the massive collections of documents such as proposals or annual reports – in the form of a set of related topics. Using a publicly available computer program, we performed topic modeling on three different NSF research portfolios by examining project abstracts: gender research, general STEM education, and teacher education and professional development.
